thread.title: Golden Knights chase Niemi early in rout of Canadiens

author: Reuters Editorial
title: Golden Knights chase Niemi early in rout of Canadiens
text:
Reilly Smith had two goals and an assist and Jonathan Marchessault tied his career-high for points in a game with three assists as the Vegas Golden Knights cruised to a 6-3 victory over the Montreal Canadiens on Saturday afternoon at T-Mobile Arena in Las Vegas.
Nate Schmidt, Ryan Carpenter, Brad Hunt and Tomas Nosek also scored goals and Marc-Andre Fleury had 30 saves for the Western Conference-leading Golden Knights, who tied the NHL record for most home wins (22) by a team in its inaugural season set by Gordie Howe and the 1979-80 Hartford Whalers. Vegas improved to 22-4-2 at home, outscoring opponents 103-64.
Charles Hudon, Nikita Scherbak and Jonathan Drouin scored for Montreal, which lost its fifth straight game and for the 11th time in its last 12 road games. The Canadiens, who defeated Vegas, 3-2, in their first meeting on Nov. 7 in Montreal, are an NHL worst 8-19-1 on the road and have won just six games since Christmas.
The Golden Knights scored three goals on their first six shots of the game to chase Montreal starting goalie Antti Niemi after just 9:51 while building a 3-1 lead. Smith started the scoring barrage with a power play goal at 2:16, but Montreal came to back to tie it when Hudon blew past Hunt down the right side and beat Fleury for his eighth goal of the season.
Vegas regained the lead on a Hunt blast from the left point that beat Neimi, who was screened by Nosek, on the glove side. Nosek followed with his fifth goal of the season three minutes later to make it 3-1 and send Niemi to the bench in favor of Carey Price, coming in off a 5-2 loss at Arizona on Thursday.
Scherbak, taking advantage of a Vegas defensive breakdown that left him all alone on the right side, scored his first goal of the season, skating in and deking Fleury to make to 3-2.
But Vegas took control in a 37-second span early in the second period. Carpenter, picked up on waivers from San Jose, scored his fifth goal in seven games when he picked up a loose puck in the slot and fired it under Priceâ€™s glove. Smith followed with his 19th goal with a back-hand rebound of a shot by defenseman Deryk Engelland.
Nate Schmidt increased the Vegas lead to 6-2 with a rebound shot that bounced off the glove of Price, who finished with 24 saves, at the 4:02 mark of the third period. Drouin ended the scoring four minutes later with a power play goal after Fleury received a penalty for interference after smashing Hudon into the net.
--Field Level Media
